maml:description.maml:para: Add a Folder to Environment Variable PATH
Add Folders to Environment Variable PATH for Machine, User or Process scope And removes missing PATH locations
Folder or Folders to add to PATH
Which Env Path the directory gets added to. Machine, User or Process
Display updated PATH variable

Display updated PATH variable
Folder or Folders to add to PATH
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Which Env Path the directory gets added to. Machine, User or Process

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Add-EnvPath -Path 'C:\temp' -VariableTarget Machine

Path of Font File, can accept multiple font files Supported File Types - .ttc, .ttf, .fnt, .otf, .fon

{{ Fill Remove Description }}
Path of Font File, can accept multiple font files Supported File Types - .ttc, .ttf, .fnt, .otf, .fon

maml:description.maml:para: Converts a file length to a human readable format.
Converts a file length to a human readable format.
The file length to convert.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The file length to convert.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Author: Woz

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Convert-FileLength -Length 123456789

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the file length 123456789 to a human readable format.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ChildItem | Select-Object -ExpandProperty Length | Convert-FileLength

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the file lengths of all files in the current directory to a human readable format.

maml:description.maml:para: Converts a SecureString to a plain text string.

The Convert-SecureString function decrypts a SecureString object and returns the corresponding plain text string. It accepts a SecureString or types convertible to SecureString, thanks to the SecureStringTransform attribute.

Specifies the SecureString to convert. This parameter can accept a SecureString, a regular string (which will be converted to a SecureString), or a PSCredential object (from which the password will be extracted). The parameter accepts input from the pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Specifies the SecureString to convert. This parameter can accept a SecureString, a regular string (which will be converted to a SecureString), or a PSCredential object (from which the password will be extracted). The parameter accepts input from the pipeline.

dev:type.maml:name: Outputs the plain text representation of the SecureString.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function uses .NET interop to convert the SecureString, and it ensures that memory is securely cleaned up after the conversion to avoid leaving sensitive data in memory.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $SecureString = ConvertTo-SecureString 'PlainTextPassword' -AsPlainText -Force Convert-SecureString -SecureString $SecureString # This example shows how to convert a plaintext password to a SecureString and then back to a plaintext string.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $Credential = Get-Credential $Credential | Convert-SecureString # This example demonstrates converting the password from a PSCredential object into a plaintext string.

maml:description.maml:para: Encodes or decodes URLs based on the specified mode.
This function encodes or decodes one or more URLs. It supports pipeline input and can process multiple URLs in sequence. Uses the UrlEncode and UrlDecode methods from the System.Net.WebUtility class
The URL(s) to encode or decode. This parameter accepts an array of strings.
The mode of operation. Can be either 'Encode' or 'Decode'. Default is 'Decode'.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The mode of operation. Can be either 'Encode' or 'Decode'. Default is 'Decode'.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The URL(s) to encode or decode. This parameter accepts an array of strings.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Convert-UrlEncoding -Url "http://example.com/test?name=John Smith" -Mode 'Encode' # Returns: http://example.com/test?name=John%20Smith

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "http://example.com/test?name=John%20Smith" | Convert-UrlEncoding -Mode 'Decode' # Returns: http://example.com/test?name=John Smith

maml:description.maml:para: Converts file paths between Windows and Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) formats.

The Convert-WSLPath function converts file paths from Windows format to WSL format and vice versa. It leverages the wslpath command available in WSL to perform the conversion. The function can process multiple paths at once and can accept paths through the pipeline. Note that this function requires WSL to be installed and accessible on the system.
Specifies the path(s) to convert. This parameter accepts an array of strings and can also accept input from the pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Converts the specified path(s) from WSL format to Windows format.
Specifies the path(s) to convert. This parameter accepts an array of strings and can also accept input from the pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Converts the specified path(s) from Windows format to WSL format. This is the default behavior if no parameter set is specified.
Specifies the path(s) to convert. This parameter accepts an array of strings and can also accept input from the pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Converts the specified path(s) from WSL format to Windows format.
Converts the specified path(s) from Windows format to WSL format. This is the default behavior if no parameter set is specified.

maml:alert.maml:para: - Paths should be provided in the correct format for the desired conversion direction (WSL to Windows or vice versa). Mixing path formats is not supported and may result in errors.
- This function requires the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) to be installed and accessible on the system.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Convert-WSLPath -Path '/mnt/c/Users/example' -ToWindows C:\Users\example

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts a WSL path to its Windows equivalent.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: 'c:\Users\example' | Convert-WSLPath -ToWSL /mnt/c/Users/example

dev:remarks.maml:para: Takes a Windows path from the pipeline and converts it to WSL format.

maml:description.maml:para: Convert Text to TitleCase
Converts input text to title case based on the specified or current culture.
The text to convert to title case.
The culture info to use for title casing, defaults to current culture.

The culture info to use for title casing, defaults to current culture.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: ConvertTo-TitleCase -Text 'testing'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ChildItem -Path D:\temp | Select-Object -ExpandProperty Name | ConvertTo-TitleCase

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves COM objects from the Windows Registry that match specified filter criteria.

The Get-ComObject function searches the HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT registry hive for COM objects that match a given pattern and optionally filters them based on user-provided strings. It checks each registry key to see if it conforms to a typical COM object naming format and contains a CLSID subkey.
An array of strings used to filter the COM objects by their names. The function will only return names that contain any of the specified strings. Each string is treated in a case-insensitive manner.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
An array of strings used to filter the COM objects by their names. The function will only return names that contain any of the specified strings. Each string is treated in a case-insensitive manner.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: This function handles registry access and object disposal safely to prevent resource leaks. Errors in accessing registry keys are silently ignored, which is useful in environments with varying access permissions.
Acknowledgments: The original version of this function was provided by https://github.com/ImportTaste

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ComObject -Filter 'Microsoft', 'Excel' This example retrieves all COM objects whose names contain either "Microsoft" or "Excel".

maml:description.maml:para: Gets Encoding for BOM and Non-BOM text files.

Returns the encoding of text files. For BOM-encoded files, the fast .NET methods are used, and confidence level is always 100%. For Non-BOM-encoded files, extensive heuristicts are applied, and confidence level varies depending on file content. Heuristics are calculated by a porting of the Mozilla Universal Charset Detector (https://github.com/errepi/ude) Important: this library is subject to the Mozilla Public License Version 1.1, alternatively licensed either under terms of GNU General Public License Version 2 or later, or GNU Lesser General Public License Version 2.1 or later.
Path to text file
Returns information for BOM-encoded files only.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Returns information for BOM-encoded files only.
Path to text file
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Make sure you respect the license terms of the ported charset detector DLL.
Source: https://github.com/TobiasPSP/GetEncoding/blob/main/Modules/EncodingAnalyzer/1.0.3/loader.psm1

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Encoding -Path c:\sometextfile.txt Returns the encoding of the text file specified

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ChildItem -Path $home -Filter *.txt -Recurse | Get-Encoding Returns the encoding of any text file found anywhere in the current user profile.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the directories listed in the PATH environment variable.
The Get-EnvPath function lists all directories specified in the PATH environment variable for a specified scope: either the current user or the machine.
Specifies the scope of the environment variable. Acceptable values are 'Machine' and 'User'. The default is 'Machine'.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the scope of the environment variable. Acceptable values are 'Machine' and 'User'. The default is 'Machine'.

dev:type.maml:name: Each line of output represents a directory in the PATH environment variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-EnvPath Lists all directories in the PATH environment variable for the machine.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-EnvPath -VariableTarget User Lists all directories in the PATH environment variable for the current user.

maml:description.maml:para: Download GitHub User Gists & Repositories using REST API and ConcurrentQueue collections for improved performance

Uses git.exe to clone the gists and repositories of a github user. You can filter repositories by name and language. -Exclude parameter will exclude any repositories that match the string/strings listed. To filter by programming language use FilterByLanguage to enable the filter by language feature then use the -Languages parameter to list the programming languages you want downloaded
Requires git.exe
The name of the user whose repositories are to be downloaded
Directory where the user's repositories are to be downloaded. Repositories are downlaoded to $Path\GITHUB_USERNAME\REPOSITORY_NAME
Exclude repositories whose names match the string/strings defined with -Exclude
Specifies the number of script blocks to clone a specific repository that run in parallel. The default value is 5.
The languages to filter repositories for when FilterByLanguage switch is used.
GitHub API token. If not set, function checks for env:GITHUB_TOKEN and uses that for the Token parameter if it exists.
When this switch is used it will filter repositories who language is not specified in the -Languages parameter.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Exclude repositories whose names match the string/strings defined with -Exclude
When this switch is used it will filter repositories who language is not specified in the -Languages parameter.
The languages to filter repositories for when FilterByLanguage switch is used.
Directory where the user's repositories are to be downloaded. Repositories are downlaoded to $Path\GITHUB_USERNAME\REPOSITORY_NAME
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the number of script blocks to clone a specific repository that run in parallel. The default value is 5.
GitHub API token. If not set, function checks for env:GITHUB_TOKEN and uses that for the Token parameter if it exists.
The name of the user whose repositories are to be downloaded

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-GitHubUserRepo -UserName WozNet -Path 'V:\git\users' -Exclude 'docs'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: 'WozNet','PowerShell','Microsoft' | Get-GitHubUserRepo -Path 'V:\git\users' -Exclude 'azure,'office365'

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves DNS host entry information for given IP addresses or hostnames.

The Get-HostEntry function queries DNS to get the host entry information for a specified list of IP addresses or hostnames. It accepts input directly or via the pipeline and outputs the corresponding System.Net.IPHostEntry objects.

Specifies the IP address or hostname for which to get the host entry information. This parameter accepts an array of strings, each representing an IP address or hostname. It can also accept input from the pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Specifies the IP address or hostname for which to get the host entry information. This parameter accepts an array of strings, each representing an IP address or hostname. It can also accept input from the pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

dev:type.maml:name: You can pipe a string array of IP addresses or hostnames to Get-HostEntry.
Returns an array of IPHostEntry objects that represent the DNS host entry information for each IP address or hostname provided.

maml:alert.maml:para: Ensure that the input addresses or hostnames are valid. The function validates if each input is a well-formed IP address or URI but does not verify their existence in DNS.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-HostEntry -Address 'www.example.com' Retrieves the host entry information for 'www.example.com'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: '8.8.8.8', '8.8.4.4' | Get-HostEntry Retrieves the host entry information for the IP addresses '8.8.8.8' and '8.8.4.4' using pipeline input.

maml:description.maml:para: Get the actual values of parameters which have manually set (non-null) default values or values passed in the call

Unlike $PSBoundParameters, the hashtable returned from Get-ParameterValues includes non-empty default parameter values. NOTE: Default values that are the same as the implied values are ignored (e.g.: empty strings, zero numbers, nulls).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: https://gist.github.com/elovelan/d697882b99d24f1b637c7e7a97f721f2/

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: function Test-Parameters { [CmdletBinding()] param( $Name = $Env:UserName, $Age ) $Parameters = Get-ParameterValues # This WILL ALWAYS have a value... Write-Host $Parameters["Name"] # But this will NOT always have a value... Write-Host $PSBoundParameters["Name"] }

maml:description.maml:para: Get the actual values of parameters which have manually set (non-null) default values or values passed in the call

Unlike $PSBoundParameters, the hashtable returned from Get-ParameterValues includes non-empty default parameter values. NOTE: Default values that are the same as the implied values are ignored (e.g.: empty strings, zero numbers, nulls).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: function Test-Parameters { [CmdletBinding()] param( $Name = $Env:UserName, $Age ) $Parameters = Get-ParameterValues # This WILL ALWAYS have a value... Write-Host $Parameters["Name"] # But this will NOT always have a value... Write-Host $PSBoundParameters["Name"] }

Enable Microsoft Updates

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to Get-PSWinUpdates.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the public IP address of the local system.

The Get-PublicIP function queries an external service to find the public IP address of the system on which it is run. It supports two different services: ipinfo.io and ifconfig.me, allowing the user to choose based on preference or availability. Each service provides the IP information in JSON format.
Specifies the api tool used to fetch the public IP address. The valid choices are 'ifconfig' and 'ipinfo'. - 'ipinfo' uses the URL 'https://ipinfo.io/json' to retrieve the IP information.
- 'ifconfig' uses the URL 'https://ifconfig.me/all.json' to retrieve the IP information.
The default is 'ipinfo'.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the api tool used to fetch the public IP address. The valid choices are 'ifconfig' and 'ipinfo'. - 'ipinfo' uses the URL 'https://ipinfo.io/json' to retrieve the IP information.
- 'ifconfig' uses the URL 'https://ifconfig.me/all.json' to retrieve the IP information.
The default is 'ipinfo'.

maml:alert.maml:para: Ensure that the machine running this script has internet access and permissions to make outbound HTTP requests.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-PublicIP Retrieves the public IP using the default 'ipinfo' service at 'https://ipinfo.io/json'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-PublicIP -Tool ifconfig Retrieves the public IP using the 'ifconfig' service at 'https://ifconfig.me/all.json'.

maml:description.maml:para: Checks URI redirection using HTTP HEAD requests.

'Get-RedirectedUrl' determines if URIs redirect to other locations by performing HTTP HEAD requests. It can operate in synchronous mode, processing each URI sequentially, or in asynchronous mode, handling multiple URIs in parallel for enhanced efficiency.
Specifies an array of absolute URIs for HTTP HEAD requests. Mandatory and accepts pipeline input.
Switches to synchronous operation, processing URIs sequentially.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Switches to synchronous operation, processing URIs sequentially.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies an array of absolute URIs for HTTP HEAD requests. Mandatory and accepts pipeline input.

dev:type.maml:name: You can pipe a string array of absolute URIs to Get-RedirectedUrl.
Outputs the final redirected URL for each input URI.

maml:alert.maml:para: This script requires the System.Net.Http assembly

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-RedirectedUrl -Uri 'http://example.com', 'http://example.org'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: 'http://example.com', 'http://example.org' | Get-RedirectedUrl -NoAsync

maml:description.maml:para: Asynchronously retrieves the final redirected URL(s) of the given URI(s).

The Get-RedirectedUrlAsync function performs asynchronous HTTP HEAD requests to the specified URI(s) and retrieves the final redirected URL(s). It is designed to handle multiple URIs efficiently by making concurrent HTTP requests.
Specifies the URI(s) for which to retrieve the final redirected URL. The URI must be an absolute URI. This parameter accepts multiple URIs and supports pipeline input.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the URI(s) for which to retrieve the final redirected URL. The URI must be an absolute URI. This parameter accepts multiple URIs and supports pipeline input.

dev:type.maml:name: You can pipe a string array of absolute URIs to Get-RedirectedUrlAsync.
Outputs the final redirected URL for each input URI.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function requires the System.Net.Http assembly and uses the HttpClient class for asynchronous web requests. It is ideal for scenarios where performance is a concern and multiple URIs need to be processed.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-RedirectedUrlAsync -Uri 'https://aka.ms/ad/list' #Result: https://github.com/microsoft/aka#readme This example retrieves the final redirected URL for 'https://aka.ms/ad/list'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: 'https://aka.ms/admin', 'https://aka.ms/ad/list' | Get-RedirectedUrlAsync #Result: https://admin.microsoft.com/ # https://github.com/microsoft/aka#readme This example demonstrates using the function with pipeline input to retrieve redirected URLs for multiple URIs.

maml:description.maml:para: Calculates the relative path from one directory to another.
This function returns the relative path from a base directory to a target path. It can be useful in scripts where path manipulation is required.
The target path for which the relative path is calculated.
The base path from which the relative path is calculated. Defaults to the current working directory.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The target path for which the relative path is calculated.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The base path from which the relative path is calculated. Defaults to the current working directory.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-RelativePath -Path "C:\Windows\System32" -RelativeTo "C:\Windows" # Returns: "..\System32"

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "C:\Windows\System32" | Get-RelativePath -RelativeTo "C:\Windows" # Returns: "..\System32"

maml:description.maml:para: Shortens a filesystem path based on the width of the PowerShell window.
This function takes a filesystem path and shortens it if necessary to fit within one-third of the PowerShell window's width, focusing on preserving the end of the path.
The filesystem path to shorten. If not provided, defaults to the current working directory.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The filesystem path to shorten. If not provided, defaults to the current working directory.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ShortPath -Path "C:\Users\ExampleUser\Documents\PowerShell\Scripts\VeryLongDirectoryName"

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "C:\Users\ExampleUser\Documents\PowerShell\Scripts\VeryLongDirectoryName" | Get-ShortPath

maml:description.maml:para: Upgrades all outdated Chocolatey packages.
The Invoke-ChocoUpgradeAll function checks for outdated Chocolatey packages and optionally upgrades them. It requires Chocolatey to be installed and accessible in the system PATH.
If specified, the function will only check for outdated packages without performing any upgrades.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
If specified, the function will only check for outdated packages without performing any upgrades.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:type.maml:name: You cannot pipe input to this function.
Dependent on the Chocolatey command output.
If -CheckOnly is specified, outputs the list of outdated packages. Otherwise, it outputs the results of the upgrade process.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function requires Chocolatey to be installed on the system and throws an error if 'choco.exe' is not found.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-ChocoUpgradeAll This example checks for outdated Chocolatey packages and upgrades them.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-ChocoUpgradeAll -CheckOnly This example only checks for outdated packages without upgrading them.

maml:description.maml:para: Downloads a file from a specified URL.

The Invoke-Download function downloads a file from the internet using a specified URL. It supports various parameters to control the download process, such as setting a custom user agent, specifying the destination folder, handling file overwrites, and showing download progress.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-Download -URL 'http://example.com/file.zip' -Destination 'C:\Downloads'

maml:description.maml:para: The URL of the file to download.
The local path where the file will be downloaded. If not specified, the current directory will be used.
The name of the file to save the download as. If not specified, the name is derived from the URL or content disposition.
If specified, the downloaded file will be marked as coming from the internet (Windows only).
If specified, the last modified date of the file won't be set.
If specified, existing files with the same name won't be overwritten.
If specified, the download progress won't be displayed.
If specified, the downloaded file object will be output to the pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The temporary path where the file will be initially downloaded.

command:parameter.maml:name: UserAgent

maml:description.maml:para: An array of user agent strings to use for the download request. Defaults to common browser user agents.

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: @('Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/116.0.0.0 Safari/537.36', 'Googlebot/2.1 (+http://www.google.com/bot.html)')

maml:description.maml:para: If specified, the downloaded file will be marked as coming from the internet (Windows only).
The local path where the file will be downloaded. If not specified, the current directory will be used.
The name of the file to save the download as. If not specified, the name is derived from the URL or content disposition.
If specified, the last modified date of the file won't be set.
If specified, existing files with the same name won't be overwritten.
If specified, the download progress won't be displayed.
If specified, the downloaded file object will be output to the pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The temporary path where the file will be initially downloaded.
The URL of the file to download.

command:parameter.maml:name: UserAgent

maml:description.maml:para: An array of user agent strings to use for the download request. Defaults to common browser user agents.

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: @('Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/116.0.0.0 Safari/537.36', 'Googlebot/2.1 (+http://www.google.com/bot.html)')

dev:type.maml:name: You can pipe a URL to Invoke-Download.
If -PassThru is specified, the function outputs the downloaded file object.

maml:alert.maml:para: Source: https://github.com/DanGough/PsDownload/blob/main/PsDownload/Public/Invoke-Download.ps1

maml:description.maml:para: Executes a script block within the context of specified directories. If a file is specified the script block is run in the directory of that file.

The Invoke-InDirectory function is designed to execute a provided script block in one or more specified directories. This functionality is particularly useful for commands that are dependent on the current directory context, such as file system operations, git commands, or running scripts that use relative paths.

Specifies one or more paths in which the script block will be executed. When a file is specified the parent directory is used. The function changes to each directory and executes the script block. This parameter accepts pipeline input and can be specified by property name. A validation script ensures that each path provided exists.

Defines the script block that will be executed in the context of each specified directory. The script block should contain the commands that you want to run. This parameter is mandatory and cannot be empty.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Specifies one or more paths in which the script block will be executed. When a file is specified the parent directory is used. The function changes to each directory and executes the script block. This parameter accepts pipeline input and can be specified by property name. A validation script ensures that each path provided exists.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Defines the script block that will be executed in the context of each specified directory. The script block should contain the commands that you want to run. This parameter is mandatory and cannot be empty.

dev:type.maml:name: You can pipe string paths, file objects, or directory objects to Invoke-InDirectory.
Depends on the script block's output. The function outputs whatever the script block returns for each directory.

maml:alert.maml:para: Remember to ensure that the script block commands are appropriate for the directory context and that they handle any relative path dependencies correctly.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-InDirectory -Path 'C:\Projects\Project1' -ScriptBlock { Get-ChildItem }

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example executes 'Get-ChildItem' in the 'C:\Projects\Project1' directory.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ChildItem -Path 'C:\Projects\' -Directory | Invoke-InDirectory -ScriptBlock { git status }

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example fetches all directories under 'C:\Projects\' and runs 'git status' in each of them.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: 'C:\Projects\Project1', 'C:\Projects\Project2' | Invoke-InDirectory -ScriptBlock { git pull }

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example demonstrates using the function with pipeline input to execute 'git pull' in both 'C:\Projects\Project1' and 'C:\Projects\Project2'.

maml:description.maml:para: Parses a PowerShell script, scriptblock, or function definition to extract used commands and variables.

The Invoke-Parser function analyzes PowerShell code from a file, a code snippet, or a function definition. It extracts and lists all the commands and variables used in the input. It supports three modes of input: File, Code, and FunctionName.
Specifies a string containing a block of PowerShell code. The function parses the code to extract commands and variables.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the name of a PowerShell function. The function parses the function definition to extract commands and variables.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the path to a PowerShell script file. The function parses the file and extracts commands and variables used in it.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies a string containing a block of PowerShell code. The function parses the code to extract commands and variables.
Specifies the name of a PowerShell function. The function parses the function definition to extract commands and variables.
Specifies the path to a PowerShell script file. The function parses the file and extracts commands and variables used in it.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-Parser -Path 'C:\temp\random-script.ps1' Parses the PowerShell script at the specified path and returns the commands and variables used in the script.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-Parser -Code '$a = 1; Write-Output $a' Parses the provided code snippet and returns the commands and variables used in it.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-Parser -FunctionName 'Get-Process' Parses the definition of the 'Get-Process' function and returns the commands and variables used in it.

maml:description.maml:para: Opens files in the PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE) editor.
The Invoke-psEdit function is designed to open specified files directly in the PowerShell ISE editor. It is especially useful for quickly editing scripts or text files within the ISE environment.
Specifies the path(s) to the file(s) to be opened in PowerShell ISE. The function accepts multiple file paths and can also accept input from the pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the path(s) to the file(s) to be opened in PowerShell ISE. The function accepts multiple file paths and can also accept input from the pipeline.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

dev:type.maml:name: You can pipe a string array of file paths to Invoke-psEdit.
This function does not produce any output. It opens files in the PowerShell ISE.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function only works within the PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE). It will throw an error if executed in a different PowerShell host.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-psEdit -Path 'C:\Scripts\MyScript.ps1' This example opens the file 'MyScript.ps1' located at 'C:\Scripts\' in PowerShell ISE.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: 'C:\Scripts\Script1.ps1', 'C:\Scripts\Script2.ps1' | Invoke-psEdit This example demonstrates the use of pipeline input to open multiple files in PowerShell ISE.

maml:description.maml:para: Encodes or decodes a URL.

The Invoke-UrlUtility function performs encoding or decoding of URLs. It uses the System.Net.WebUtility class to perform the operations. By default, it decodes URLs, but it can also encode them based on the action parameter.
Specifies the URL(s) to be encoded or decoded. This parameter accepts an array of strings and supports pipeline input.
Specifies the action to be performed on the URL(s). The valid actions are 'Encode' and 'Decode'. The default action is 'Decode'.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the action to be performed on the URL(s). The valid actions are 'Encode' and 'Decode'. The default action is 'Decode'.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the URL(s) to be encoded or decoded. This parameter accepts an array of strings and supports pipeline input.

dev:type.maml:name: You can pipe a string array to Invoke-UrlUtility.
Invoke-UrlUtility returns the encoded or decoded URL(s).

maml:alert.maml:para: This function can handle multiple URLs at once if provided as an array or via pipeline input. It uses the .NET System.Net.WebUtility class for encoding and decoding.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-UrlUtility -Url 'https://www.example.com?q=PowerShell%20Scripts' This example decodes the URL 'https://www.example.com?q=PowerShell%20Scripts'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-UrlUtility -Url 'https://www.example.com?q=PowerShell Scripts' -Action Encode This example encodes the URL 'https://www.example.com?q=PowerShell Scripts'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: 'https://www.example.com?q=PowerShell%20Scripts' | Invoke-UrlUtility This example demonstrates pipeline input, decoding the URL.

maml:description.maml:para: Joins a base URI with a child path segment.

The Join-Url function takes a base URI and a child path segment, and combines them into a single well-formed URI. It handles the proper inclusion of slashes between the base and child segments. By default, it outputs the combined URI as a string, but it can also return a URI object.
The base URI to which the child path will be appended. It must be a valid URI.
The child path segment to append to the base URI.
If specified, the function returns the result as a [uri] object. Otherwise, it returns a string.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The base URI to which the child path will be appended. It must be a valid URI.
The child path segment to append to the base URI.
If specified, the function returns the result as a [uri] object. Otherwise, it returns a string.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Join-Url -Base 'http://example.com' -Child 'path/segment'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Join-Url -Base 'http://example.com' -Child '/path/segment' -OutUri

maml:description.maml:para: Builds an ANSI escape sequence string for setting the foreground or background color.

The New-AnsiString function generates an ANSI escape sequence string that can be used to set the foreground or background color in a console application. It supports specifying the color using RGB values or predefined color names.
Specifies the red component of the RGB color. Must be an integer between 0 and 255. If not provided, a random value between 0 and 255 will be used.
Specifies the green component of the RGB color. Must be an integer between 0 and 255. If not provided, a random value between 0 and 255 will be used.
Specifies the blue component of the RGB color. Must be an integer between 0 and 255. If not provided, a random value between 0 and 255 will be used.
Specifies whether the color should be applied to the foreground or background. Valid values are 'Foreground' and 'Background'. The default value is 'Foreground'.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the color using a predefined color name. The available color names can be tab-completed. If not provided, a random RGB color will be used.
Specifies whether the color should be applied to the foreground or background. Valid values are 'Foreground' and 'Background'. The default value is 'Foreground'.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies whether to reset the color to the default. If this switch is present, all other parameters will be ignored.
Specifies whether the color should be applied to the foreground or background. Valid values are 'Foreground' and 'Background'. The default value is 'Foreground'.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the blue component of the RGB color. Must be an integer between 0 and 255. If not provided, a random value between 0 and 255 will be used.
Specifies the color using a predefined color name. The available color names can be tab-completed. If not provided, a random RGB color will be used.
Specifies whether the color should be applied to the foreground or background. Valid values are 'Foreground' and 'Background'. The default value is 'Foreground'.
Specifies the green component of the RGB color. Must be an integer between 0 and 255. If not provided, a random value between 0 and 255 will be used.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the red component of the RGB color. Must be an integer between 0 and 255. If not provided, a random value between 0 and 255 will be used.
Specifies whether to reset the color to the default. If this switch is present, all other parameters will be ignored.

dev:type.maml:name: The ANSI escape sequence string that sets the specified color.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $Ansi = New-AnsiString -Red 255 -Green 0 -Blue 0 -ColorTarget 'Foreground' $Reset = New-AnsiString -Reset $Text = 'Add your text here...' '{0}{1}{2}' -f $Ansi, $Text, $Reset Saves the ANSI escape sequence for the color and reset Ansi strings to their own variables. To apply the color to text simply put the $Ansi variable before the text followed by the reset ansi color to default.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $AnsiFG1 = New-AnsiString -Red 55 -Green 120 -Blue 190 -ColorTarget 'Foreground' $AnsiBG1 = New-AnsiString -Green 100 -ColorTarget 'Background' $Reset = New-AnsiString -Reset $Text = 'This is a test. More testing... and testing' $Text2 = 'More and more and more!' '{0}{1}{2}{3}{4}' -f $AnsiFG1, $Text, $AnsiBG1, $Text2, $Reset This example sets both the foreground and background colors for different parts of a text.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-AnsiString -Reset Returns the ANSI escape sequence string for resetting the color to the default.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new development folder (DevPad) and optionally sets an environment variable.

The New-DevPad function creates a folder for development purposes based on the current date and optionally sets a user environment variable 'DevPad' to this folder's path. The folder is created under a specified path or defaults to 'D:_dev\DPad'.
Specifies the base path where the DevPad folder will be created. The default path is 'D:_dev\DPad'. The final folder includes the current year and date.
Skip setting the 'DevPad' environment variable.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Skip setting the 'DevPad' environment variable.
Specifies the base path where the DevPad folder will be created. The default path is 'D:_dev\DPad'. The final folder includes the current year and date.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-DevPad -Path 'C:\MyDevFolders' Creates a new DevPad folder under 'C:\MyDevFolders' and the 'DevPad' environment variable is set to this folder's path.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-DevPad -NoEnvVariable Creates a new DevPad folder in the default location ('D:\_dev\DPad') without setting the environment variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the last commit time as the last write time for files in a Git repository.

The `Set-GitFileCommitTime` function updates the last write time of files in a Git repository to match their last commit time. This can be useful for build systems, backup solutions, or any scenario where file timestamps need to reflect their version control history. The function supports processing paths from the pipeline and can operate in a verbose mode for additional output details. It also includes a stopwatch feature to measure the duration of the operation.

Specifies the path to the Git repository. This can be a full path or a relative path. If not specified, it defaults to the current working directory. The function verifies the existence of a .git directory at the specified path.
Returns an object with the path and updated commit time for each file processed. This parameter is useful for piping output to further processing commands.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Includes a stopwatch timer to measure the duration of the operation. When specified, the function outputs the total time taken to complete the process.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Returns an object with the path and updated commit time for each file processed. This parameter is useful for piping output to further processing commands.

Specifies the path to the Git repository. This can be a full path or a relative path. If not specified, it defaults to the current working directory. The function verifies the existence of a .git directory at the specified path.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Includes a stopwatch timer to measure the duration of the operation. When specified, the function outputs the total time taken to complete the process.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:alert.maml:para: - Requires Git to be installed and accessible in the system's PATH.

- The function is optimized for PowerShell 7.0 and above with parallel processing capabilities for improved performance. On versions below 7.0, the function will revert to sequential processing and issue a warning.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Set-GitFileCommitTime -Path C:\Path\To\Repo

dev:remarks.maml:para: Updates the last write time of all files in the specified Git repository to match their last commit time.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ChildItem -Path C:\Repos\ -Directory | Set-GitFileCommitTime -PassThru

dev:remarks.maml:para: Finds all directories under C:\Repos and updates the file timestamps in each Git repository found. Outputs the details of the processed files.

maml:description.maml:para: Test the pending reboot status on a local and/or remote computer. Updated to be compatible with powershell 7+, converted Invoke-WmiMethod to Invoke-CimMethod.

This function will query the registry on a local and/or remote computer and determine if the system is pending a reboot, from Microsoft/Windows updates, Configuration Manager Client SDK, Pending Computer Rename, Domain Join, Pending File Rename Operations and Component Based Servicing.

ComponentBasedServicing = Component Based Servicing WindowsUpdate = Windows Update / Auto Update CCMClientSDK = SCCM 2012 Clients only (DetermineifRebootPending method) otherwise $null value PendingComputerRenameDomainJoin = Detects a pending computer rename and/or pending domain join PendingFileRenameOperations = PendingFileRenameOperations, when this property returns true, it can be a false positive PendingFileRenameOperationsValue = PendingFilerenameOperations registry value; used to filter if need be, Anti-Virus will leverage this key property for def/dat removal, giving a false positive
A single computer name or an array of computer names. The default is localhost ($env:COMPUTERNAME).

Specifies a user account that has permission to perform this action. The default is the current user. Type a username, such as User01, Domain01\User01, or User@Contoso.com. Or, enter a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a user name, you are prompted for a password.
Indicates that this function returns a detailed result of pending reboot information, why the system is pending a reboot, not just a true/false response.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Indicates that this function will not test the Client SDK WMI class that is provided by the System Center Configuration Manager Client. This parameter is useful when SCCM is not used/installed on the targeted systems.

Indicates that this function will not test the PendingFileRenameOperations MultiValue String property of the Session Manager registry key. This parameter is useful for eliminating possible false positives. Many Anti-Virus packages will use the PendingFileRenameOperations MultiString Value in order to remove stale definitions and/or .dat files.
A single computer name or an array of computer names. The default is localhost ($env:COMPUTERNAME).

Specifies a user account that has permission to perform this action. The default is the current user. Type a username, such as User01, Domain01\User01, or User@Contoso.com. Or, enter a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a user name, you are prompted for a password.
Indicates that this function returns a detailed result of pending reboot information, why the system is pending a reboot, not just a true/false response.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

Indicates that this function will not test the Client SDK WMI class that is provided by the System Center Configuration Manager Client. This parameter is useful when SCCM is not used/installed on the targeted systems.

Indicates that this function will not test the PendingFileRenameOperations MultiValue String property of the Session Manager registry key. This parameter is useful for eliminating possible false positives. Many Anti-Virus packages will use the PendingFileRenameOperations MultiString Value in order to remove stale definitions and/or .dat files.

maml:alert.maml:para: Author: Woz Updated: 12-4-2023
Original Author: Brian Wilhite Email: bcwilhite (at) live.com

Background: https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/heyscriptingguy/2013/06/10/determine-pending-reboot-statuspowershell-style-part-1/ https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/heyscriptingguy/2013/06/11/determine-pending-reboot-statuspowershell-style-part-2/
Component-Based Servicing: http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc756291(v=WS.10).aspx
PendingFileRename/Auto Update: http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2723674 http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc960241.aspx http://blogs.msdn.com/b/hansr/archive/2006/02/17/patchreboot.aspx
CCM_ClientSDK: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj902723.aspx

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Test-PendingReboot

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example returns the ComputerName and IsRebootPending properties.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: (Test-PendingReboot).IsRebootPending True

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will return a bool value based on the pending reboot test for the local computer.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Test-PendingReboot -ComputerName DC01 -Detailed

dev:remarks.maml:para: ComputerName : dc01 ComponentBasedServicing : True PendingComputerRenameDomainJoin : False PendingFileRenameOperations : False PendingFileRenameOperationsValue : SystemCenterConfigManager : False WindowsUpdateAutoUpdate : True IsRebootPending : True
This example will test the pending reboot status for dc01, providing detailed information

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Test-PendingReboot -ComputerName DC01 -SkipConfigurationManagerClientCheck -SkipPendingFileRenameOperationsCheck -Detailed

dev:remarks.maml:para: CommputerName : dc01 ComponentBasedServicing : True PendingComputerRenameDomainJoin : False PendingFileRenameOperations : False PendingFileRenameOperationsValue : SystemCenterConfigManager : WindowsUpdateAutoUpdate : True IsRebootPending : True

maml:description.maml:para: Tests if a given URI string is well-formed.
The Test-Url function checks if the provided URI string is well-formed according to the specified URI kind (Absolute or Relative).
Specifies the URI string to be tested. This parameter is mandatory and accepts input from the pipeline.
Specifies the kind of the URI to be tested (Absolute or Relative). The default is Absolute.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the URI string to be tested. This parameter is mandatory and accepts input from the pipeline.
Specifies the kind of the URI to be tested (Absolute or Relative). The default is Absolute.

dev:type.maml:name: Returns True if the URI is well-formed, otherwise returns False.

maml:alert.maml:para: Use this function to validate URI strings in your scripts, especially when working with web requests or handling user input.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Test-Url -Uri 'http://www.example.com'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns True if the URL is well-formed, otherwise returns False.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: 'www.example.com' | Test-Url

dev:remarks.maml:para: Tests the URI string received from the pipeline and returns True if it is well-formed, otherwise False.

maml:description.maml:para: Formats and writes a custom error object based on a provided error record.

The Write-CustomError function takes an error record and creates a custom object that includes detailed information about the error. This custom object contains the type of the exception, the exception message, the reason for the error, the target of the error, and the location in the script where the error occurred.
Specifies the error record to be formatted into a custom error object. This should be an instance of System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Specifies the error record to be formatted into a custom error object. This should be an instance of System.Management.Automation.ErrorRecord.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

dev:type.maml:name: Outputs a custom object with detailed error information.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function is useful for standardizing error handling and logging in scripts and functions.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to use Write-CustomError in a try-catch block to format and handle errors.

maml:description.maml:para: Displays a progress bar within a Windows PowerShell command window.
The Write-MyProgress cmdlet displays a progress bar in a Windows PowerShell command window that depicts the status of a running command or script.
A switch parameter to clean up any uncleared progress bars.
Specifies an ID that distinguishes each progress bar from the others.
Specifies the parent activity of the current activity.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
A status message to display in the progress bar.
The current position within the loop.
Specifies an ID that distinguishes each progress bar from the others.
The collection of objects being processed in the loop.
Specifies the parent activity of the current activity.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The start time of the process.
A status message to display in the progress bar.
A switch parameter to clean up any uncleared progress bars.
The current position within the loop.
Specifies an ID that distinguishes each progress bar from the others.
The collection of objects being processed in the loop.
Specifies the parent activity of the current activity.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
